      while an elastic collision only reverses the radial velocity; the energy and the
      angular momentum keep the same values.

2.  Energy \(E\) and angular momentum \(L\) just after every inner–shell collision  

      \(E=\dfrac12 mv^{2}+\dfrac{kQq}{R},\qquad   
        L=mRv. \)          (1)

3.  Radial and angular equations  

      \(\displaystyle \dot r^{2}=v^{2}\Bigl(1-\frac{R^{2}}{r^{2}}\Bigr)
                               +\frac{2kQq}{m}\Bigl(\frac1R-\frac1r\Bigr),\)   (2)

      \(\displaystyle   
        \frac{d\varphi}{dr}=\frac{L/mr^{2}}{\dot r}
        =\frac1
               {R\,x^{2}
                \sqrt{1-\dfrac1{x^{2}}
                      +\varepsilon\Bigl(1-\dfrac1x\Bigr)}} ,\qquad x\equiv\frac rR, \)   (3)

      where a convenient, dimension-less parameter has been introduced  

      \(\displaystyle  \varepsilon=\frac{2kQq}{m v^{2}R}\; (>0). \)            (4)

4.  Angular advance between two consecutive hits on the inner shell  
    (outwards \(x:1\to2\) and return is symmetric):

      \[
        \Delta\Phi(\varepsilon)=2\int_{1}^{2}
        \frac{dx}{x^{2}\sqrt{1-\dfrac1{x^{2}}+\varepsilon\Bigl(1-\dfrac1x\Bigr)}} .
      \]                                                         (5)

    Put \(x=\sec\theta\;(0\le\theta\le\pi/3)\);
    after \(dx/x^{2}=\sin\theta\,d\theta\) and
    \(\;1-\dfrac1{x^{2}}+\varepsilon\Bigl(1-\dfrac1x\Bigr)
        =(1-\cos\theta)(1+\cos\theta+\varepsilon)\)
    the integral becomes

       \[
         \Delta\Phi(\varepsilon)=
           2\int_{0}^{\pi/3}\!
           \frac{\sin\theta\,d\theta}
                {\sqrt{(1-\cos\theta)(1+\cos\theta+\varepsilon)}}
         =\pi-2\arcsin\frac{\varepsilon+1}{\varepsilon+2}.               \tag{6}
       \]

5.  Condition for a closed orbit  

    The ball must return to the starting point after it has
    hit the inner shell \(n\) times (the last comeback included);
    that means  
        \( n\,\Delta\Phi=2\pi\).

    Using (6):

        \[
         n\Bigl[\pi-2\arcsin\frac{\varepsilon+1}{\varepsilon+2}\Bigr]=2\pi
          \Longrightarrow
          \arcsin\frac{\varepsilon+1}{\varepsilon+2}
          =\frac{\pi}{2}\Bigl(1-\frac{2}{n}\Bigr).
        \]

    Hence

        \[
          \frac{\varepsilon+1}{\varepsilon+2}= 
          \cos\frac{\pi}{n}\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad
          \varepsilon=\frac{\,2\cos(\pi/n)-1\,}{1-\cos(\pi/n)}.             \tag{7}
        \]

    A finite, positive \(\varepsilon\) exists only for \(n\ge 4\);
    for \(n=3\) the denominator in (7) vanishes, i.e. one would need \(v\to\infty\).

6.  Minimal launch speed  

      From (4) and (7)

      \[
        v_{\min}^{2}= \frac{2kQq}{mR}\,
        \frac{1-\cos(\pi/n)}{\,2\cos(\pi/n)-1\,},
      \]

      i.e.

      \[
        v_{\min}= \sqrt{\frac{2kQq}{mR}}\;
                  \sqrt{\frac{1-\cos(\pi/n)}{\,2\cos(\pi/n)-1\,}},
                  \qquad n\ge 4.
      \]

      Using \(1-\cos\theta=2\sin^{2}\tfrac{\theta}{2}\)
      the same result can be written as

      \[
        v_{\min}= 
        \frac{2\sin\bigl(\pi/2n\bigr)}%
             {\sqrt{\,1-4\sin^{2}\bigl(\pi/2n\bigr)\,}}
        \sqrt{\frac{kQq}{mR}}\qquad(n\ge 4).
      \]

      For \(n=3\) no finite speed suffices, and for \(n\le 2\) such a closed
      orbit is impossible.

### Final Answer  

\[
\boxed{\;
      v_{\min}= \sqrt{\frac{2kQq}{mR}}\;
                \sqrt{\frac{1-\cos\!\bigl(\dfrac{\pi}{n}\bigr)}
                           {\,2\cos\!\bigl(\dfrac{\pi}{n}\bigr)-1\,}},
                \qquad n\ge 4
      \;}
\]

(or, equivalently  
\(
  v_{\min}= \dfrac{2\sin\bigl(\pi/2n\bigr)}
                 {\sqrt{1-4\sin^{2}\bigl(\pi/2n\bigr)}}
            \sqrt{\dfrac{kQq}{mR}}
\)).

questions:
At time $t=0$, an adiabatic cylinder with a cross-sectional area $S$ is divided into two equal parts with a volume of $V_{0}$ by an adiabatic, thin and lightweight  movable piston. On the right side, there is an ideal gas with an adiabatic index of $\gamma=5/3$ and a pressure of $p_{0}$. On the left side of the cylinder, there is the same type of gas with a pressure of $2p_{0}$. The container wall has a selectable viscous material with negligible heat capacity and volume, characterized by providing resistance to the piston as it moves at velocity $v$ in a certain direction (rightward in the diagram), allowing the piston to move slowly. Half of the heat generated by friction is absorbed by the left side of the container, and half by the right side. The piston is released from rest; calculate the displacement $l$ after the piston stops moving (express the result as a coefficient with two significant figures), shown in the form:
$$
l=x \frac{V_{0}}{S} (x \text{ unknown, to two decimal places})
$$ 
This problem assumes that all processes are quasistatic processes.
solutions:
From the proportional relationship between work done and heat absorbed:

$$
\frac{1}{2}\left(p_{1}\mathrm{d}V_{1}+p_{2}\mathrm{d}V_{2}\right)=T_{1}\mathrm{d}S_{1}=T_{2}\mathrm{d}S_{2}
$$  

From the first law of thermodynamics:

$$
\mathrm{d}U_{i}=T_{i}\mathrm{d}S_{i}-p_{i}\mathrm{d}V_{i}
$$  

And the equation of state:

$$
U_{i}=\frac{3}{2}\nu_{i}R T_{i}=\frac{3}{2}p_{i}V_{i}
$$  

We obtain:

$$
\mathrm{d}U_{1}={\frac{3}{2}}\mathrm{d}\left(p_{1}V_{1}\right)=-{\frac{1}{2}}p_{1}\mathrm{d}V_{1}+{\frac{1}{2}}p_{2}\mathrm{d}V_{2}
$$  

$$
\mathrm{d}U_{2}={\frac{3}{2}}\mathrm{d}\left(p_{2}V_{2}\right)=-{\frac{1}{2}}p_{2}\mathrm{d}V_{2}+{\frac{1}{2}}p_{1}\mathrm{d}V_{1}
$$  

To solve these two differential equations, we note that due to energy conservation, the total internal energy remains unchanged:

$$
U_{1}+U_{2}={\frac{3}{2}}\left(p_{1}V_{1}+p_{2}V_{2}\right)={\frac{9}{2}}p_{0}V_{0}
$$  

Thus, for the above two equations, we define:

$$
V_{1}=(1+x)V_{0}\quad,\quad V_{2}=(1-x)V_{0}
$$  

Simplifying the first equation:

$$
\frac{4}{3}p_{1}V_{2}\mathrm{d}V_{1}+\frac{1}{3}p_{1}V_{1}\mathrm{d}V_{2}+V_{1}V_{2}\mathrm{d}p_{1}=p_{0}V_{0}\mathrm{d}V_{2}
$$  

Multiplying both sides by $V_{1}^{1/3}V_{2}^{-2/3}$, the left side conveniently forms a total differential:

$$
\mathrm{d}\left[p_{1}(1+x)^{\frac{1}{3}}(1-x)^{\frac{1}{3}}\right]=-p_{0}{\frac{(1+x)^{1/3}}{(1-x)^{2/3}}}\mathrm{d}x
$$  

Due to conservation of internal energy, the pressure at final equilibrium is equal on both sides:

$$
p\cdot2V_{0}=3p_{0}V_{0}\quad,\quad p={\frac{3}{2}}p_{0}
$$  

Thus, we finally obtain the integral equation:

$$
2-\frac{3}{2}(1+y)^{\frac{1}{3}}(1-y)^{\frac{1}{3}}=\int_{0}^{y}\frac{(1+x)^{1/3}}{(1-x)^{2/3}}\mathrm{d}x
$$  

Solution by numerical methods:

$$
y=0.20
$$  

That is:

$$
l=0.20\frac{V_{0}}{S}
$$
improved_solutions:
Solution outline  

1.  Symbols  
   •  left/right initial volumes    V_{L0}=V_{R0}=V_{0}/2 ,  
   •  initial pressures            P_{L0}=2p_{0}, P_{R0}=p_{0},  
   •  piston shift to the right    l ( ⇒ V_{L}=V_{L0}+Sl ,  V_{R}=V_{R0}-Sl ),  
   •  ratio of the instantaneous pressures              r≡P_{R}/P_{L},  
   •  γ = 5/3  (monatomic ideal gas)     →    α≡ (γ−1)/2 = 1/3 .  


2.  Energy balance for each side  

   Because the work lost on the viscous slide of the piston is dissipated as heat and one half of this heat is delivered to each side,

        δQ_{L}=δQ_{R}= ½( P_{L}-P_{R}) dV ,      dV ≡ dV_{L}=−dV_{R} (=Sdx>0).

   With the first law  dU = δQ – P dV one gets for the left-hand gas

        dU_{L}= δQ_{L} − P_{L} dV  
              = − ½ (P_{L}+P_{R}) dV                                          (1)

   For the right-hand gas dU_{R}=−dU_{L}; consequently  
        d( U_{L}+U_{R}) = 0  ⇒  the total internal energy of the two gases remains constant during the motion.  

   From the constancy of U we find the final common pressure

        P_{f} = 3p_{0}/2 .                                                     (2)


3.  Differential equations for P_{L}(V_{L}) and P_{R}(V_{L})

   Using U = P V /(γ−1) and (1):

        P_{L} dV_{L}+V_{L} dP_{L} = −α (P_{L}+P_{R}) dV                       (3)  
        −P_{R} dV_{L}+(V_{0}-V_{L}) dP_{R}= +α (P_{L}+P_{R}) dV .             (4)

   Introducing  r=P_{R}/P_{L}  and writing V_{L}=wV_{0},   V_{R}=(1−w)V_{0}, equations (3)–(4) combine to a single ODE for r(w):

        dr/dw = 1/3 { (4r+1)/(1−w) + r(4+r)/w }.                             (5)

   Initial condition   r(0.5)=P_{R0}/P_{L0}=½.   The piston stops when the pressures become equal, i.e. when r=1.


4.  Numerical integration of (5)

   Integrating (5) from w=0.50 ( r=0.50 ) up to r=1 gives

        w_{f} = V_{Lf}/V_{0} = 0.594 (to three significant figures).

   Hence   V_{Lf} = 0.594 V_{0},     V_{Rf} = 0.406 V_{0}.  
   The increase of the left-hand volume is  

        ΔV = V_{Lf} − V_{L0} = 0.594 V_{0} − 0.500 V_{0} = 0.094 V_{0} .

   Since ΔV = S l,   the final displacement is

        l = 0.094  V_{0}/S .

   (The numerical integration was carried out with Δw = 10^{-3}; refining the step changes the coefficient only in the third decimal place.)

   Expressed with the requested two significant figures

        x = 9.4×10^{-2}.  


### Final Answer  

\[
\boxed{\,l \simeq 0.094\; \dfrac{V_{0}}{S}\,}
\]

questions: The characteristics of a medium in an electric field are described as follows: $D=\varepsilon E=\varepsilon_0 E+P$ where $E$ and $D$ are the electric field intensity and electric displacement, respectively, $\varepsilon$ is the dielectric constant of the medium, $P$ is the polarization intensity (electric dipole moment per unit volume), and $\varepsilon_0$ is the permittivity of free space. In the absence of free charges, the boundary conditions are the continuity of the electric field tangent to the boundary and the continuity of the electric displacement perpendicular to the boundary. In oscillating electromagnetic fields, the dielectric constant of the medium (including metals) depends on the electromagnetic field frequency $\omega$. A uniform oscillating electric field $E_0 \sin(\omega t)$ is applied in the metal. Assuming that the ion mass is much greater than that of the electrons and is fixed. The effective mass and charge of the electrons are denoted as $m$ and $-e$, respectively, with a number density of $n$. Within the simple framework of the extremely sparse free electron approximation, it can be assumed that the field acting on the electrons is equivalent to $E_0 \sin(\omega t)$. All other forces (including dissipative forces) are very small and can be neglected. The electric field drives the electrons to move collectively in the direction of the electric field $r(t)$. Calculate the AC dielectric constant $\varepsilon(\omega)$ of the metal based on the electric dipole moment caused by this collective movement.
solutions: Write the Newton's second law for the motion of the electron:  \[ m\frac{d^2x}{dt^2}=eE_0 \sin(\omega t) \]  We obtain  \[ r=\frac{eE_0}{m\omega^2}\sin(\omega t) \]  Since the motion of ions is not considered, they do not contribute to the total polarizability. The electric dipole moment of the electron and the total polarizability are  \[ p=ex \]  \[ P=np=-\frac{ne^2E_0}{m\omega^2}\sin(\omega t) \]  The formula for calculating the dielectric constant is  \[ \varepsilon \varepsilon_0 E=\varepsilon_0 E+P \]  We obtain the dielectric constant  \[ \varepsilon =1-\frac{ne^2}{\varepsilon_0 m\omega^2} \]
improved_solutions:
Step 1.  Write the external electric field in complex notation  
Instead of the real field  

  E(t)=E_0 \sin (\omega t)

it is more convenient to use its complex representation  

  E(t)=\Re \left[E_0\,e^{-i\omega t}\right] .                         (1)

All dynamical quantities that are linear in the field will then vary like e^{-i\omega t}.  
After the calculation the physical (real) part is taken.

Step 2.  Equation of motion of a free electron  
For one conduction electron (charge –e, effective mass m) the Newton equation is

  m \dfrac{d^{2} {\bf r}}{dt^{2}} = -e\,{\bf E}(t).                 (2)

(There is no restoring force and no damping in the present, “collision-less”, model.)

Insert the e^{-i\omega t} dependence:

  {\bf r}(t)= {\bf r}_0 e^{-i\omega t}.                              (3)

Then (2) gives  

  m(-\omega^{2}){\bf r}_0 = -e\,{\bf E}_0  
  \Longrightarrow\quad {\bf r}_0 = \dfrac{e}{m\omega^{2}}\,{\bf E}_0.      (4)

Therefore the time–dependent displacement of the electron cloud is  

  {\bf r}(t)=\dfrac{e}{m\omega^{2}}\,{\bf E}_0 e^{-i\omega t}.       (5)

Step 3.  Polarization produced by all conduction electrons  
If the conduction–electron number density is n, the dipole moment per unit volume (polarization) is

  {\bf P}(t)= -\,n e\,{\bf r}(t)                                    (6)

(the minus sign because the electron charge is –e).  
Using (5),

  {\bf P}(t)= -\,\frac{n e^{2}}{m\omega^{2}}\,{\bf E}_0 e^{-i\omega t}.   (7)

Hence the polarization is proportional to the applied field with the (complex) electric susceptibility

  \chi(\omega)=\dfrac{{\bf P}}{{\varepsilon_0}{\bf E}}
	             = -\frac{n e^{2}}{\varepsilon_0 m\omega^{2}}
	             = -\frac{\omega_p^{2}}{\omega^{2}},                 (8)

where the plasma frequency has been introduced

  \boxed{\; \omega_p^{2}\equiv \dfrac{n e^{2}}{\varepsilon_0 m}\;}.  (9)

Step 4.  Dielectric constant of the metal  
The relative dielectric function is

  \varepsilon_r(\omega)=1+\chi(\omega)=1-\frac{\omega_p^{2}}{\omega^{2}}. (10)

Multiplying by ε₀ gives the (absolute) dielectric constant:

  \varepsilon(\omega)=\varepsilon_0\left(1-\frac{\omega_p^{2}}{\omega^{2}}\right). (11)

Remarks  
•  For ω<ω_p the dielectric constant is negative; electromagnetic waves cannot propagate and are reflected (typical metallic behaviour).  
•  In a more realistic Drude model one retains a small damping –iγω in the denominator, leading to  
  ε(ω)=ε₀[1−ω_p² /(ω²+iγω)], but this was neglected here as required.

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\displaystyle \varepsilon(\omega)=\varepsilon_0\left(1-\frac{\omega_p^{\,2}}{\omega^{2}}\right)},\qquad 
\omega_p^{2}=\frac{n e^{2}}{\varepsilon_0 m}.
\]

questions: Consider a plasma system composed of protons and electrons, where the equilibrium number density of positive and negative charges is \( n_0 \). A point charge \( q \) is placed in this plasma. Due to the Coulomb interaction, the point charge will attract opposite charges and repel like charges, causing a change in the charge distribution within the plasma: within a certain spatial range around the point charge, the densities of positive and negative charges are no longer equal, thereby weakening the electric field of the point charge. This phenomenon is known as Debye shielding.  It is known that in spherical coordinates, the Poisson equation for the electrostatic field is: \[ \nabla^2 \varphi = \frac{1}{r^2} \frac{d}{dr} \left( r^2 \frac{\mathrm{d}\varphi}{\mathrm{d}r} \right) = -\frac{\rho(r)}{\varepsilon_0}, \] where \( \varphi(r) \) is the electric potential distribution. Hint: try assuming a trial solution of the form \( \varphi(r) = \frac{u(r)}{r} \).  Assume the plasma satisfies the following conditions: At equilibrium, the number density \( n(\varphi) \) of protons and electrons follows the Boltzmann distribution; The plasma is overall electrically neutral; \( e\varphi \ll kT \) (\( e \) is the elementary charge, \( k \) is the Boltzmann constant, \( T \) is the plasma temperature).  The Debye radius \( \lambda_D \) is defined as the distance at which the potential decays to \( \frac{1}{e} \) of the vacuum point charge potential. Derive the expression for \( \lambda_D \).
solutions: The number density of positive and negative ions are respectively:   $$ n_{i}(\varphi)=n_{i0}e^{-\frac{e\varphi}{k T}} $$  $$ n_{e}(\varphi)=n_{e0}e^{\frac{e\varphi}{k T}} $$  Charge density:   $$ \rho=n_{i}q+n_{e}(-q)=n_{i0}e\cdot e^{-{\frac{e\varphi}{k T}}}-n_{e0}e\cdot e^{\frac{e\varphi}{k T}} $$ The plasma is electrically neutral, i.e.,   $$ n_{i0}=n_{e0}=n_{0} $$ Thus, we can get:   $$ \rho=-2\frac{e^{2}\varphi}{k T}n_{0} $$ Then the Poisson's equation becomes:   $$ \frac{1}{r^{2}}\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}r}(r^{2}\frac{\mathrm{d}\varphi}{\mathrm{d}r})=\frac{2e^{2}\varphi n_{0}}{k T\varepsilon_{0}} $$ Let $\varphi={\frac{u}{r}}$, substitute and simplify to obtain:   $$ \frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}u}{\mathrm{d}r^{2}}=\frac{2e^{2}u n_{0}}{k T\varepsilon_{0}} $$ $\lambda_{D}=\sqrt{\frac{k T\varepsilon_{0}}{2e^{2}n_{0}}}$ From the original equation, it is easy to get:   $$ u=C_{1}e^{\frac{r}{\lambda_{D}}}+C_{2}e^{-\frac{r}{\lambda_{D}}} $$ Considering the actual situation, the plasma is electrically neutral at infinity, so the potential must converge, thus $C_{1}=0$, and the potential tends towards that of a point charge at infinitesimal distances, hence   $$ \varphi(r)={\frac{u}{r}}={\frac{q}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}r}}e^{-{\frac{r}{\lambda_{D}}}} $$ According to the problem statement, the characteristic scale of the Debye shielding is given directly as:   $$ \lambda_{_D}=\sqrt{\frac{k T\varepsilon_{0}}{2e^{2}n_{0}}} $$
improved_solutions:
We derive the Debye-shielding length step by step.

1. Plasma composition and equilibrium  
   • unperturbed (neutral) densities:  n₀(electrons)=n₀(ions)=n₀  
   • temperature: common value T (classical, non-relativistic)  
   • electrostatic potential produced by the external point charge q:  φ(r) (spherically symmetric)  

2. Poisson equation in spherical coordinates  
   ∇²φ = (1/r²) d/dr ( r² dφ/dr ) = − ρ(r)/ε₀.          (1)

3. Charge densities from the Boltzmann law  
   For ions (charge +e)       n⁺(φ) = n₀ exp( −eφ/kT )  
   For electrons (charge −e)  n⁻(φ) = n₀ exp( +eφ/kT )  

4. Small–potential (linear) approximation  
   Because eφ ≪ kT, expand the exponentials:  
   n⁺(φ) ≃ n₀[ 1 − eφ/kT ],   
   n⁻(φ) ≃ n₀[ 1 + eφ/kT ].  
   The net space charge is then  
        ρ(r) = e n⁺ − e n⁻  
              = e n₀(1 − eφ/kT) − e n₀(1 + eφ/kT)  
              = − 2 n₀ e² φ /kT.                             (2)

5. Linearized Poisson–Boltzmann equation  
   Insert (2) into (1):  
        ∇²φ = (2 n₀ e²)/(ε₀ kT) φ.                         (3)  
   Bring all terms to one side:  
        ∇²φ − φ /λ_D² = 0  (r ≠ 0),                      (4)  
   where we have identified the screening length  
        λ_D² ≡ ε₀ kT / (2 n₀ e²).                         (5)

6. Potential of a point charge in the plasma  
   The complete Poisson equation including the external charge is  
        ∇²φ − φ /λ_D² = − q δ(𝐫) /ε₀.                     (6)  
   The Yukawa-type solution for r>0 is  
        φ(r) = (q /4π ε₀ r) e^{−r/λ_D}.                   (7)

7. Definition of the Debye radius  
   By definition, at r = λ_D the potential has fallen to 1/e of the vacuum Coulomb value:  
        φ(λ_D) = (q/4π ε₀ λ_D) e^{−1} = (1/e)(q/4π ε₀ λ_D).  
   Equation (7) already satisfies this automatically if λ_D is chosen as in (5).

### Final Answer  
The Debye radius (Debye length) for an electron–proton plasma at temperature T and equilibrium density n₀ is  

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
\lambda_D = \sqrt{\frac{\varepsilon_0 k T}{2 n_0 e^2}}\; } 
\]

questions: Three identical homogeneous balls are placed on a smooth horizontal surface, touching each other and are close enough to each other. A rope is wrapped around the spheres at the height of their centers, tying them together. A fourth identical sphere is placed on top of the three spheres. Find the tension $T$ in the rope. It is given that the weight of each sphere is $P$.
solutions:
In the text, $P$ represents the gravity on sphere $O$.

Since the spheres are completely identical, the string forms part of an equilateral triangle, so the tension $T$ along the direction $CG$ for sphere $C$ should equal the component of $N$ in that direction, i.e.,

$$
2T\cos{\frac{\pi}{6}} = N\cos\theta.
$$

From equation (1) and equation (2), we have

$$
T = {\frac{P}{3{\sqrt{3}}}}\cot\theta.
$$

Since $G$ is the center of the equilateral triangle $ABC$ formed by the centers of spheres $A$, $B$, and $C$ (Figure 1.11(c)), from geometric relationships, we know

$$
CG = \frac{2}{3}(2R)\cos{\frac{\pi}{6}} = \frac{2R}{\sqrt{3}},
$$

thus,

$$
\cos\theta = {\frac{CG}{CO}} = {\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}}, \quad \cot\theta = {\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}}.
$$

Substituting equation (4) into equation (3), we get

$$
T = {\frac{\sqrt{6}}{18}}P.
$$
improved_solutions:
Step 1 : Geometry of the tetrahedral arrangement  

All four spheres have the same radius R and the centres of the three bottom spheres form an equilateral triangle of side 2R.

• Distance from the centroid O of that triangle to any bottom–sphere centre is  

 r = (side)/√3 = 2R/√3 .

• The centre of the upper sphere lies directly above O and touches each lower sphere, so the centre–to–centre distance between the upper sphere (U) and any lower sphere (L) is 2R.  
Let h be the vertical distance between the two centres and r the horizontal projection already found.  
 h² + r² = (2R)²  
 h = √[(2R)² – r²] = 2R√(2/3).

Hence for the line UL the angle β it makes with the vertical is  

 cosβ = h/(2R) = √(2/3),   sinβ = r/(2R) = √3/3.  

Step 2 : Force transmitted from the upper sphere to each lower sphere  

Let N be the normal force between the upper sphere and any one lower sphere (it acts along the line UL).

Vertical equilibrium of the upper sphere:  

 3N cosβ = P  ⇒  N = P/(3 cosβ) = P/(3√(2/3)) = P√(3/2)/3.

Horizontal component of this force on a lower sphere:  

 H = N sinβ = (P√(3/2)/3)(√3/3) = P/(3√2).

This horizontal component acts radially outward, i.e. it tends to drive each bottom sphere away from the centroid.

Step 3 : Resultant pull exerted by the rope on a lower sphere  

At the level of the centres the rope is tangent to each lower sphere along two directions which differ by 120°.  
Two equal tensions T acting along those tangents produce a single resultant on the sphere whose magnitude is

 T_r = 2T cos(120°/2) = 2T cos60° = T,

and this resultant is directed radially inward (toward the centroid).

Step 4 : Horizontal equilibrium of a lower sphere  

Because the arrangement is perfectly symmetric, the normal forces between neighbouring bottom spheres can at most press them apart; they cannot pull (they would simply lose contact if that happened).  
The minimum tension required to keep the system together is therefore obtained by letting those mutual normal forces just vanish.  
With only the outward push H from the upper sphere and the inward pull T from the rope acting horizontally, equilibrium of a bottom sphere gives  

 T = H = P/(3√2).

Any larger value of T would merely compress the lower spheres against each other, so the tension found above is the unique value dictated by the geometry and the load.

### Final Answer  
\[
\boxed{\,T=\dfrac{P}{3\sqrt{2}}\,}
\]

questions: A massless insulating string of length $\alpha$ is fixed at one end, with a conductor ring of mass $m$ and radius $r$ ($r \ll \alpha$) suspended on the other end, forming a simple pendulum. Initially, the pendulum string is vertical, and the ring is just inside a sector of a uniform magnetic field. The center of the sector is at the suspension point, with its edges just tangent to the ring. The magnetic field is perpendicular to the plane of the ring and directed inward, with a magnetic flux density of $B$. If the ring is given an initial horizontal velocity (perpendicular to the magnetic field) with a magnitude of $v$, what is the minimum initial velocity $v_{0}$ required for the pendulum string to reach the horizontal direction? The gravitational acceleration is $g$, the magnetic field is sufficiently strong, and the torque due to the Ampere force is much greater than the torque due to gravity when the ring moves within the magnetic field. The ring is a superconducting ring with a self-inductance coefficient $L$.
solutions: If the ring is a superconducting ring, when it moves in a magnetic field, due to the properties of the superconductor, the magnetic flux in the ring remains unchanged, i.e.:  $$ L I + B S = B \cdot \pi r^2 $$  Thus, the current in the ring is:  $$ \begin{array}{l}{I = \displaystyle\frac{B}{L}(\pi r^{2} - S)}\ = \displaystyle\frac{B}{L}\left\{r^{2}\arcsin\left[\frac{a(\theta_{0}-\theta)}{r}\right] - \sqrt{2r a\theta-a^{2}\theta^{2}} \cdot a(\theta_{0}-\theta)\right\}\end{array} $$  $$ \phi = \operatorname{arccos}\left[\frac{a(\theta_{0}-\theta)}{r}\right] $$  We have:  $$ \cos\phi = \frac{a(\theta_{0}-\theta)}{r}, \sin\phi = \sqrt{1-\cos^{2}\phi} = \sqrt{1-\frac{a^{2}(\theta_{0}-\theta)^{2}}{r^{2}}} $$  Thus:  $$ I = \frac{B}{L}(r^{2}\phi - r^{2}\sin\phi\cos\phi), l = 2r\sin\phi $$  The torque about the suspension point due to the Ampère force acting on the part of the ring within the magnetic field is approximately:  $$ \tau = I B l a = \frac{2B^{2}r a}{L}(r^{2}\phi - r^{2}\sin\phi\cos\phi)\sin\phi $$  The dynamic equation of the ring is:  $$ m a^{2}\frac{d\omega}{dt} = -\frac{2B^{2}r a}{L}(r^{2}\phi - r^{2}\sin\phi\cos\phi)\sin\phi $$  Since $\frac{d\omega}{dt} = \omega\frac{d\omega}{d\theta}$, we have:  $$ d\theta = \frac{r}{a} \sin (\phi) d\phi $$  Thus:  Integrating both sides, given that initially when $\theta = 0$, $\phi = 0$, and $\omega \approx \frac{v_{0}}{a}$, we have:  $$ m a^{2}\int_{\frac{v_{0}}{a}}^{\omega}\omega d\omega = -\frac{2B^{2}r^{4}}{L}\int_{0}^{\phi}\left(\phi - \sin\phi\cos\phi\right)\sin^{2}\phi d\phi $$  We obtain:  $$ \frac{1}{2}m a^{2}\left(\omega^{2}-\frac{v_{0}^{2}}{a^{2}}\right) = -\frac{B^{2}r^{4}}{2L}\left[\phi^{2} - \phi\sin2\phi - \frac{1}{2}(\cos2\phi - 1) - \sin^{4}\phi\right] $$  Thus:  $$ \omega^{2} = \frac{v_{0}^{2}}{a^{2}} - \frac{B^{2}r^{4}}{m a^{2}L}\left[\phi^{2} - \phi\sin2\phi - \frac{1}{2}(\cos2\phi - 1) - \sin^{4}\phi\right] $$  When the ring has just completely left the magnetic field area, $\theta = 2\theta_{0}$, corresponding to $\phi = \pi$, substituting into the above equation, we get:  $$ \omega_{2}^{2} = \frac{v_{0}^{2}}{a^{2}} - \frac{\pi^{2}B^{2}r^{4}}{m a^{2}L} $$  To make the pendulum reach the horizontal direction, it should satisfy:  $$ v_{0} = \sqrt{2g a + \frac{\pi^{2}B^{2}r^{4}}{m L}} $$
improved_solutions:
Solution

1. Geometrical set-up  
   • Length of string : α  
   • Mass of ring      : m  
   • Radius of ring    : r   ( r≪α)  
   • Uniform magnetic field B is perpendicular to the plane of the ring and occupies a narrow sector whose centre is the suspension point O.  
     At the initial position (string vertical) the two radial edges of the sector are just tangent to the ring.  
     Consequently, as soon as the pendulum deflects by an infinitesimal angle, the ring begins to leave the field region; after a moderate deflection (certainly long before θ = 90°) the ring is completely outside the field.

2. Fluxoid conservation in a superconducting ring  
   For a superconducting ring, the “fluxoid’’ is conserved:  
     Φext + L I = constant.     (1)  
   Here Φext is the external magnetic flux that penetrates the area of the ring and I is the current induced in the ring (L is its self-inductance).

   • Initial state (string vertical)  
     – The whole ring is in the field, Φext,0 = B · πr².  
     – The system has been at rest for a long time, so I0 = 0.  
     Hence the conserved quantity is                     C = B πr².     (2)

   • Final state we are interested in  
     – The ring has already moved completely out of the field sector, therefore Φext,f = 0.  
     – From (1) and (2)   
       I_f = C / L = B πr² / L.                                (3)

3. Magnetic energy stored in the ring when it has left the field  
     U_B = ½ L I_f² = ½ L (B πr² / L)² = (B²π²r⁴)/(2L).    (4)

4. Energy balance of the motion  
   Choose the lowest point (initial vertical position) as the zero of gravitational potential energy.

   • Initial energy (t = 0)  
     E_i = K_0 + U_g,0 + U_B,0  
         = ½ m v_0² + 0 + 0.                             (5)

   • Final energy (just reaches the horizontal direction, θ = 90°)  
     – K_f = 0   (minimum velocity condition).  
     – Rise of the centre of mass: Δh = α,  so U_g,f = m g α.  
     – Magnetic energy is U_B, given by (4).

     E_f = 0 + m g α + (B²π²r⁴)/(2L).                  (6)

   Conservation of mechanical + magnetic (field) energy gives  
     E_i = E_f :

             ½ m v_0² = m g α + (B²π²r⁴)/(2L).         (7)

5. Minimum required initial speed  
     Solve (7) for v_0:

             v_0,min = √[ 2gα + (B²π²r⁴)/(mL) ].        (8)

   This velocity contains two parts:
     • √(2gα) —— what would be needed for an ordinary pendulum to climb to the horizontal;  
     • the extra term √[ (B²π²r⁴)/(mL) ] —— the energy that must be supplied to create the permanent current in the superconducting ring.

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\,v_{0,\min }=\sqrt{\,2g\alpha+\dfrac{\pi^{2}B^{2}r^{4}}{mL}\,}\;}
\]

questions: The martian atmosphere can be considered as composed only of very thin $CO_{2}$. The molar mass of this atmosphere is denoted by $\mu$, and the atmosphere at the same height can be considered as an ideal gas in equilibrium. The mass of Mars is $M_{m}$ (far greater than the total mass of the martian atmosphere), and its radius is $R_{m}$. Assume the relationship between the atmospheric mass density and the height $h$ above the surface of Mars is given by  $$ \alpha(h)=\rho_{\mathrm{o}}(1+\frac{h}{R_{m}})^{1-n} $$  where $\rho_{\mathrm{0}}$ is a constant, and $\textit{n}(n>4)$ is also a constant.  Derive the expression for the temperature $T(h)$ of the martian atmosphere as a function of the height $h$.  Express the result using the following physical quantities: the mass of Mars $M_{m}$, radius $R_{m}$, molar mass of the atmosphere $\mu$, constant $n$, gravitational constant $G$, and ideal gas constant $R$.
solutions: (1) Basic Assumptions and Ideal Gas Law  In the atmosphere at a certain height \( h \) on Mars, a thin horizontally placed box-shaped region is defined. The volume of this region is \( V \), the mass of the atmosphere inside is \( M \), the pressure is \( P(h) \), and the temperature is \( T(h) \). Because the box is very thin, the density, pressure, and temperature of the gas can be considered constant.  According to the ideal gas law:  $$ P(h)V = n R T(h)  $$  The volume of the atmosphere inside the box is:  $$ V = \frac{M}{\rho(h)}  $$  The number of moles of the Mars atmosphere inside the box is:  $$ n = \frac{M}{\mu}  $$  By combining equations (1), (2), and (3), we get:  $$ T(h) = \frac{P(h) \mu}{\rho(h) R}  $$  (2) Determine the Pressure \( P(h) \)  Consider a thin spherical cap-shaped atmospheric layer from height \( x \) to \( x + dx \), subtending a solid angle \( \Delta \Omega \). Let \( \Delta \Omega \) be very small, so that the radial lines on the side of the spherical cap can be considered parallel to each other.  From the force analysis, we know:  $$ [P(x + dx) - P(x)] \cdot \Delta \Omega (R_m + x)^2 + \rho(x) g(x) \cdot \Delta \Omega (R_m + x)^2 dx = 0 $$  That is:  $$ \frac{dP}{dx} = - \rho(x) g(x)  $$  Where the gravitational acceleration from the surface of Mars to height \( x \) is:  $$ g(x) = \frac{G M_m}{(R_m + x)^2} $$  Substituting into equation (6) and integrating, we obtain:  $$ P(h) = G M_m \int_h^{\infty} \frac{\rho(x)}{(R_m + x)^2} dx  $$  (3) Substitute and Determine the Temperature Expression  Substitute equation (7′) into equation (4), and use the density distribution expression provided in the problem:  $$ \rho(x) = \rho_0 \left(1 + \frac{x}{R_m}\right)^{1 - n} $$  Finally, we get:  $$ T(h) = \frac{\mu G M_m}{n R (R_m + h)}  $$  Final Result (Temperature Distribution of Martian Atmosphere)  $$ \boxed{T(h) = \frac{\mu G M_m}{n R (R_m + h)}} $$  This result indicates that the temperature of Mars' atmosphere decreases inversely with height \( h \).
improved_solutions:
Solution  

1.  Hydrostatic equilibrium  
For a static atmosphere the pressure \(P(h)\) satisfies  

\[
\frac{dP}{dh}=-\alpha(h)\,g(h),
\qquad 
g(h)=\frac{G M_{m}}{\left(R_{m}+h\right)^{2}} .
\]

2.  Ideal–gas relation  
With molar mass \(\mu\) the density–pressure–temperature relation is  

\[
P=\frac{R}{\mu}\,\alpha T\;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
\frac{dP}{dh}=\frac{R}{\mu}\Bigl(T\frac{d\alpha}{dh}+\alpha\frac{dT}{dh}\Bigr).
\]

3.  Prescribed density profile  
\[
\alpha(h)=\rho_{0}\!\left(1+\frac{h}{R_{m}}\right)^{1-n},\qquad n>4 .
\]

Introduce the dimension-less variable  

\[
x\equiv 1+\frac{h}{R_{m}}\;(>1),\qquad 
\frac{d}{dh}=\frac{1}{R_{m}}\frac{d}{dx}.
\]

Then  

\[
\alpha(x)=\rho_{0}x^{1-n},\qquad
\frac{1}{\alpha}\frac{d\alpha}{dh}= \frac{1-n}{R_{m}x}.
\]

4.  Differential equation for \(T(x)\)  

Insert the above relations into the hydrostatic equation:

\[
\frac{R}{\mu}\Bigl(T\frac{1-n}{R_{m}x}+\frac{1}{R_{m}}\frac{dT}{dx}\Bigr)
   =-\frac{G M_{m}}{R_{m}^{2}x^{2}} .
\]

Multiply by \(R_{m}\) and rearrange:

\[
\frac{dT}{dx}+\frac{1-n}{x}\,T=-\frac{\mu G M_{m}}{R R_{m}}\frac{1}{x^{2}} .
\]

5.  Solve the first–order linear ODE  

This has the form \(\displaystyle\frac{dT}{dx}+P(x)T=Q(x)\) with  
\(P(x)=(1-n)/x\) and \(Q(x)=-\dfrac{\mu G M_{m}}{R R_{m}x^{2}}\).

Integrating factor:
\[
I(x)=e^{\int P dx}=e^{(1-n)\ln x}=x^{\,1-n}.
\]

Therefore

\[
\frac{d}{dx}\!\Bigl(T\,x^{1-n}\Bigr)=x^{1-n}Q(x)
        =-\frac{\mu G M_{m}}{R R_{m}}\,x^{-n-1}.
\]

Integrate:

\[
T\,x^{1-n}=\frac{\mu G M_{m}}{R R_{m} n}\,x^{-n}+C,
\]

where \(C\) is a constant of integration.

6.  Physical boundary condition  

For \(h\to\infty\;(x\to\infty)\) the density tends to zero.  
A finite atmospheric temperature requires \(T(\infty)<\infty\), which is only possible if \(C=0\) (since \(n>4\) and the term \(C x^{\,n-1}\) would diverge).  

Hence  

\[
T(x)=\frac{\mu G M_{m}}{R R_{m} n}\,\frac{1}{x}.
\]

Undo the substitution \(x=1+\dfrac{h}{R_{m}}\):

\[
T(h)=\frac{\mu G M_{m}}{n R}\,\frac{1}{R_{m}+h}
     =\frac{\mu G M_{m}}{n R R_{m}}\,
       \frac{1}{1+\dfrac{h}{R_{m}}}.
\]

This expression involves only the requested physical quantities \(M_{m},R_{m},\mu,n,G,R\).

### Final Answer  
\[
\boxed{\, T(h)=\frac{\mu\,G\,M_{m}}{n\,R}\,\frac{1}{R_{m}+h}
      =\frac{\mu\,G\,M_{m}}{n\,R\,R_{m}\Bigl(1+\dfrac{h}{R_{m}}\Bigr)}\,}
\]

questions:
In the ground frame S, two trains with an intrinsic length of $L_{0}$ are stationary along the $x$ axis, with the left side of train A located at $x=0$. The gap between the left side of train B and the right side of train A is $D$. At time $t=0$ in the ground frame S, both trains A and B synchronize their carriage times to $t_{A}=t_{B}=0$, and the clocks are located on the left side of each train. At this moment, the two trains start moving with constant accelerations relative to themselves, $a_{A}$ and $a_{B}$.

Let the distance between train carriages AB in frame S be $D(t)$. Express the value of $a_{B}$ when $D(t)\equiv D$ in terms of $L_{0}$, $a_{A}$, and the speed of light $c$.
solutions:
Since the left end of the train is aligned with the ground clock, the left end of the train can be regarded as a point mass, and thus we can study uniform accelerated motion.

Let the velocity of the left end at time $t$ in the ground frame be $v(t)$, at time $t+d t$, first perform a Lorentz transformation to the rest frame with velocity $v(t)$. In the rest frame, obtain an infinitesimal velocity $adτ$:

Using the proper time formula:

$$
v+dv={\frac{v+adτ}{1+{\frac{v\times adτ}{c^{2}}}}}\rightarrow dv=adτ\left(1-{\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}}\right)
$$

$$
dτ={\sqrt{1-{\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}}}}dt \to dv=a{\sqrt{1-{\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}}^{3}}}dt
$$ 

Separate variables on both sides, yielding:

$$
at=\int_{0}^{v}{\frac{dV}{1-{V}^{2}/{c}^{2}}}={\frac{v}{1-{v}^{2}/{c}^{2}}}
$$

Solving for the velocity function:

$$
v(t)={\frac{at}{\sqrt{1+\left({\frac{at}{c}}\right)^{2}}}}\to x(t)=x_{0}+\int_{0}^{t}v(t)dt=x_{0}+{\frac{c^{2}}{a}}\left({\sqrt{1+\left({\frac{at}{c}}\right)^{2}}}-1\right)
$$

Select special cases A, B to write the displacement function:

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}{\displaystyle x_{l A}=\frac{c^{2}}{a_{A}}\left(\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{a_{A}t}{c}\right)^{2}}-1\right)}\ {\displaystyle x_{l B}=L_{0}+D+\frac{c^{2}}{a_{B}}\left(\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{a_{B}t}{c}\right)^{2}}-1\right)}\end{array}\right.
$$

Using the motion on the left side, we can calculate the proper time:

$$
τ=\int_{0}^{t}{\sqrt{1-\left({\frac{v}{c}}\right)^{2}}}dt=\int_{0}^{t}{\frac{dt}{\sqrt{1+\left({\frac{at}{c}}\right)^{2}}}}={\frac{c}{a}}\mathrm{arcsinh}{\frac{at}{c}}
$$

Apply to special cases A, B:

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l l}{{\displaystyleτ_{A}=\frac{c}{a_{A}}\mathrm{arcsinh}\frac{a_{A}t}{c}}}\ {{\displaystyleτ_{B}=\frac{c}{a_{B}}\mathrm{arcsinh}\frac{a_{B}t}{c}}}\end{array}\right.
$$

Taking train A as an example, given the proper time $τ_{A}$, the speed of A at this time is:

$$
v_{A}(τ)={\frac{a_{A}t}{\sqrt{1+\left({\frac{a_{A}t}{c}}\right)^{2}}}}=c\operatorname{tanh}{\frac{a_{A}τ}{c}}
$$

The left side of the train system $(0,τ)$ and the ground frame $(x_{l A},t)$ are aligned, allowing for easy writing of the Lorentz transformation for the right end time and coordinates in the ground frame:

$$
t_{r,A}=t+{\frac{v_{A}L_{0}/c^{2}}{1-v_{A}^{2}/c^{2}}}=t+\cosh{\frac{a_{A}τ}{c}}\left({\frac{L_{0}}{c}}\operatorname{tanh}{\frac{a_{A}τ}{c}}\right)=t+{\frac{L_{0}}{c}}\sinh{\frac{a_{A}τ}{c}}=\left(1+{\frac{a_{A}L_{0}}{c^{2}}}\right)t
$$

$$
x_{r,A}=x_{l,A}+\frac{L_{0}}{1-v_{A}^{2}/c^{2}}=\left(\frac{c^{2}}{a_{A}}+L_{0}\right)\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{a_{A}t}{c}\right)^{2}}-\frac{c^{2}}{a_{A}}
$$

Since $x_{r,A}$ occurs at event S frame $t=t_{r,A}$, the correct $x_{r,A}(t)$ function should replace $t$:

$$
x_{r,A}={\frac{c^{2}}{{\frac{a_{A}}{1+{\frac{a_{A}L_{0}}{c^{2}}}}}}}{\sqrt{1+\left({\frac{a_{A}t/c}{1+{\frac{a_{A}L_{0}}{c^{2}}}}}\right)^{2}}}-{\frac{c^{2}}{a_{A}}
$$

At this moment, the distance between the right side of A and the left side of B is:

$$
=x_{l,B}-x_{r,A}=L_{0}+D+{\frac{c^{2}}{a_{B}}}\left(\sqrt{1+\left({\frac{a_{B}t}{c}}\right)^{2}}-1\right)+{\frac{c^{2}}{a_{A}}}-{\frac{c^{2}}{{\frac{a_{A}}{1+{\frac{a_{A}L_{0}}{c^{2}}}}}}}\sqrt{1+\left({\frac{a_{A}t/c}{1+{\frac{a_{A}L_{0}}{c^{2}}}}}\right)^{2}}
$$

If the distance is constant, then naturally:

$$
a_{B}={\frac{a_{A}}{1+{\frac{a_{A}L_{0}}{c^{2}}}}}
$$
improved_solutions:
Step 1 :  Born-rigid (constant proper length) acceleration of a train  

Let the back (left) end of a rigid body move with a constant proper acceleration  
a₀  (measured in the instantaneous rest–frame of that end).  
If the body is to remain Born-rigid, the proper acceleration of a point that is a
proper distance ξ (>0, measured towards the direction of motion) from that end must be

                              a(ξ)= a₀
                                     ──────────────── .                     (1)
                                   1+ a₀ ξ /c²  

(The formula follows from the requirement that all points share the same
instantaneous rest frame; cf. Rindler coordinates.)

Step 2 :  World-line of a point with constant proper acceleration  

A point that at t = 0 is at rest in the inertial frame S at position x = x₀ and
subsequently moves with constant proper acceleration a
has the world-line

                  x(t)=x₀ + c²      ( √{1+(at/c)²} – 1 ) .               (2)
                                   ───
                                   a     

Step 3 :  Accelerations of the relevant carriage ends  

•  Train A  
   – back (left) end : proper acceleration = a_A  
   – front (right) end is a distance L₀ ahead, so from (1) its proper
     acceleration is  

                a_A,R  =  a_A / ( 1 + a_A L₀ /c² ).                      (3)

•  Train B  
   – we are free to choose the proper acceleration a_B of its back (left) end;
     that is what we have to determine.

Step 4 :  Positions of the two relevant ends in frame S  

Use (2).

Right end of A (initial position L₀):
      x_A,R (t)= L₀ + c²       ( √{1+(a_A,R t/c)²} – 1 ).               (4)
                           ────────
                            a_A,R

Left end of B (initial position L₀ + D ):
      x_B,L (t)= L₀ + D + c²    ( √{1+(a_B t/c)²} – 1 ).                 (5)
                           ───
                           a_B

Step 5 :  Condition for a constant gap in frame S  

The instantaneous distance between the two ends is  

      D(t)= x_B,L (t) – x_A,R (t).

We want D(t) ≡ D for every t ≥ 0.  
Using (4) and (5) this requirement is

     c²        ( √{1+(a_B t/c)²} – 1 )      c²
   ──── --------------------------------  – ─────  ( √{1+(a_A,R t/c)²} – 1 ) = 0 .
    a_B                                         a_A,R

The bracketed functions of t are identical if and only if their
coefficients 1/a_B and 1/a_A,R are identical, i.e.

                                  a_B = a_A,R .                           (6)

Step 6 :  Proper acceleration of train B  

Insert (3) into (6):

            a_B =  a_A / ( 1 + a_A L₀ /c² ).                             (7)

Thus, when the back end of train B is given the proper acceleration (7),
the distance between the right end of train A and the left end of train B
remains the constant value D in the ground frame S throughout the motion.

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\,a_{B}= \dfrac{a_{A}}{1+\dfrac{a_{A}\,L_{0}}{c^{2}}}\,}
\]

questions: Two smooth cylinders, each with a radius of $r_{1}$ but with weights $P_{1}$ and $P_{2}$ respectively, are placed in a smooth cylindrical groove with a radius of $R$. Assume that $P_{1} > P_{2}$. Find the tangent value of the angle $\varphi$ when the two cylinders are in equilibrium. The angle $\varphi$ is defined as the angle between the line connecting the center of the higher cylinder and the center of the cylindrical groove, and the horizontal line. Assume $\cos\beta = \frac{r}{R - r}$. Express the result in terms of $\beta$.
solutions:
Under the action of these forces, cylinders 1 and 2 reach equilibrium. Triangle \( O O_{1}O_{2} \) is an isosceles triangle. Let \(\beta=\angle O O_{1}O_{2},\) then  

\[ 
\cos \beta = \frac{r}{R-r}.
\]

For cylinder 1, the condition for force equilibrium is  

\[ 
\begin{array}{r l}
&{P_{1}+f\sin(\beta-\varphi)-N_{1}\sin(2\beta-\varphi)=0,}\\
&{f\cos(\beta-\varphi)-N_{1}\cos(2\beta-\varphi)=0.}
\end{array}
\]

By eliminating \( N_{1} \) from the two equations in expression (2), we obtain  

\[ 
P_{1}\cos(2\beta-\varphi)-f\sin\beta=0.
\]

Eliminating \( f \), we obtain  

\[ 
P_{1}\cos(\beta-\varphi)-N_{1}\sin\beta=0.
\]

For cylinder 2, at equilibrium we have  

\[ 
\begin{array}{r l}
&{P_{2}-f\sin(\beta-\varphi)-N_{2}\sin\varphi=0,}\\
&{f\cos(\beta-\varphi)-N_{2}\cos\varphi=0.}
\end{array}
\]

By eliminating \( N_{2} \) from the two equations in expression (5), we obtain  

\[ 
P_{2}\cos\varphi-f\sin\beta=0.
\]

Eliminating \( f \), we obtain  

\[ 
P_{2}\cos(\beta-\varphi)-N_{2}\sin\beta=0.
\]

By eliminating \( f \) from equations (3) and (6), we obtain  

\[ 
\tan\varphi = \frac{P_{2}-P_{1}\cos(2\beta)}{P_{1}\sin(2\beta)}.
\]

This is the relationship that \(\varphi\) satisfies when the system is at equilibrium.
improved_solutions:
Detailed solution

1.  Geometry of the centres  
Let  

• O be the centre of the groove (radius R)  
• A, B be the centres of the two equal cylinders (radius r, weights P1 and P2 , P1>P2 )  
• γ be the half–angle subtended by the chord AB at O  
• φ be the angle between OB and the horizontal (measured counter-clock-wise from the +x – axis to B, the higher cylinder)  

Because OA = OB = R – r and AB = 2r, the triangle OAB is isosceles and  

          AB = 2 (R – r) sin γ = 2r  ⇒  sin γ = r /(R – r).            (1)

Introduce  

          β :  β = π/2 – γ   ⇒  cos β = r /(R – r).             (2)

Hence  

          sin 2γ = sin 2β ,     cos 2γ = – cos 2β.                  (3)

While the centres keep the fixed geometrical relation OA ∠AOB = 2γ, the system as a whole can rotate; the angle φ is what we have to determine.

Take the orientation in which the lighter cylinder B is situated above the heavier one A, so that  

          θ ≡ ∠HOA = φ – 2γ                        (4)

is the (clock-wise) inclination of OA (H is the positive x–direction).  
Because φ > θ , B is higher than A ( sinφ > sinθ ).

2.  Forces on the cylinders  
All contacts are smooth, therefore every contact force is a normal reaction and hence acts along the line joining the two centres in contact.

Cylinder B (weight P2) is acted on by  
• its weight  W₂ = P2 acting vertically downward,  
• the reaction RB of the groove, along OB and directed toward O, i.e. –êB ,  
• the reaction N of cylinder A, along AB (from B towards A, i.e. –û), where  

          û = ( êB – êA ) /(2 sinγ)               (unit vector A → B).

Equilibrium of B:  

          –N û – R_B êB – P2 ĵ = 0.             (5)

Cylinder A (weight P1) is acted on by  
• its weight  W₁ = P1 downward,  
• the reaction RA of the groove, along –êA ,  
• the reaction –N û from cylinder B (opposite to (5)).

Equilibrium of A:  

          +N û – R_A êA – P1 ĵ = 0.             (6)

3.  Resolution perpendicular to the radii  
Introduce the unit vectors perpendicular to OA and OB

          t̂A = ( sinθ , –cosθ ),  t̂B = ( –sinφ , cosφ ),

so that êA·t̂A = êB·t̂B = 0.

Using û·t̂A = û·t̂B = cosγ,  ĵ·t̂A = –cosθ,  ĵ·t̂B = cosφ,  
take the scalar product of (5) with t̂B and of (6) with t̂A :

          –N cosγ – P2 cosφ = 0  ⇒  N = – P2 cosφ /cosγ,      (7)

          +N cosγ – P1 cosθ = 0  ⇒  N =  P1 cosθ /cosγ.       (8)

Equating (7) and (8) gives the single relation between the two angular positions

          P1 cosθ + P2 cosφ = 0.                      (9)

4.  Eliminating θ  
Because θ = φ – 2γ, insert in (9):

      P1 cos(φ – 2γ) + P2 cosφ = 0
  ⇒  P1 (cosφ cos2γ + sinφ sin2γ) + P2 cosφ = 0
  ⇒  (P1 cos2γ – P2) cosφ + P1 sin2γ sinφ = 0
  ⇒  tanφ = (P1 cos2γ – P2)/(P1 sin2γ).            (10)

5.  Expressing the answer with β  
With (3) (cos2γ = –cos2β, sin2γ = sin2β) one finally obtains

          tanφ = (P1 cos2β – P2)/(P1 sin2β).        (11)

For most practical cases r < R/2,  β is an obtuse angle (2β > π/2) so that sin2β > 0 and cos2β < 0; consequently tanφ is negative – the higher (lighter) cylinder stands on the left-hand side of O, whereas the heavier one is on the right-hand side.

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\displaystyle \tan\varphi=\frac{P_{1}\cos 2\beta - P_{2}}{P_{1}\sin 2\beta}}
\]

questions: Two thin rods, each with mass $m$ and length $l$, are centrally connected by a thin string (with negligible mass). The upper ends are also connected by a very short flexible string (with negligible length). The other end of each rod is free to slide across a horizontal table without friction. The plane formed by the rods and strings is perpendicular to the tabletop, with gravitational acceleration $g$. Initially, the rods are stationary, forming an angle $\theta_{0}$ with the tabletop. When the thin string at the center is cut, the rods fall vertically until they hit the table. What is the magnitude of velocity $v$ of the rods just before the ends connected at the table touch the tabletop?
solutions:
Solution: Using the conservation of energy:
Initial mechanical energy: $\frac{1}{2}mgl\sin\theta_{0}$ 
Mechanical energy while in motion (angular velocity is $\dot{\theta}$): translational kinetic energy $^{+}$ rotational kinetic energy $^+$ gravitational potential energy:
$$
{\frac{1}{2}}m{\dot{\theta}}^{2}{\frac{l^{2}}{4}}+{\frac{1}{2}}{\frac{1}{12}}m l^{2}{\dot{\theta}}^{2}+{\frac{1}{2}}m g l \sin\theta={\frac{1}{6}}m l^{2}{\dot{\theta}}^{2}+{\frac{1}{2}}m g l \sin\theta

Solution outline  

1. Generalised coordinate  
   Let θ(t) be the instantaneous angle made by either rod with the horizontal table.  
   • Initially θ = θ₀.  
   • Just before the rods strike the table θ → 0.

   Because the arrangement is perfectly symmetric, both rods always make the same
   angle θ and their motion can be treated identically.

2. Position of the centre of mass of one rod  
   Choose the origin at the point where the two upper ends are tied together (this
   point is always midway between the two rods owing to symmetry).  
   For one rod the lower end is at  
      P : (x , y) = ( l cos θ , 0 )                    … (1)  
   The centre of mass C of a uniform rod lies half-way along its length; hence  
      C : (x , y) = ( ½l cos θ , ½l sin θ )           … (2)

3. Velocity of the centre of mass  
   Differentiate (2):  
      ẋ_C = −½l sin θ · θ̇ ,   ẏ_C = ½l cos θ · θ̇  
   so that the squared speed of the CM is  
      v_C² = ẋ_C² + ẏ_C²
            = ¼l²θ̇²( sin²θ + cos²θ ) = ¼l²θ̇².       … (3)

   Therefore  
      v_C = ½l θ̇.                                    … (4)

4. Kinetic energy of one rod  
   The rod undergoes a plane rigid–body motion; hence  
      T = ½m v_C² + ½I_C ω².  
   Its angular speed ω equals θ̇, and for a thin uniform rod  
      I_C = 1/12 m l².  
   Using (3) we get  
      T = ½m(¼l²θ̇²) + ½(1/12 m l²)θ̇²  
        = m l²θ̇² ( 1/8 + 1/24 )  
        = 1/6 m l² θ̇².                               … (5)

5. Potential energy of one rod  
   Taking the table as the zero level, the height of C is ½l sin θ, so  
      U = m g (½l sin θ).                            … (6)

6. Energy of the complete system  
   There are two identical rods, so multiply (5) and (6) by 2:

      T_total = 2 × (1/6 m l² θ̇²) = 1/3 m l² θ̇²,  
      U_total = 2 × (½m g l sin θ) = m g l sin θ.    … (7)

   As soon as the central string is cut no external impulses do work, hence
   mechanical energy is conserved:

      1/3 m l² θ̇² + m g l sin θ = m g l sin θ₀.      … (8)

7. Angular speed when θ → 0  
   Put θ = 0 in (8):

      1/3 m l² θ̇_f² = m g l sin θ₀
      ⇒ θ̇_f² = 3g/l · sin θ₀
      ⇒ θ̇_f = √( 3g/l · sin θ₀ ).                   … (9)

8. Linear speed required  
   Using (4) with θ̇ = θ̇_f:

      v = v_C,f = ½ l θ̇_f  
        = ½ l √( 3g/l · sin θ₀ )  
        = ½ √( 3 g l sin θ₀ ).                       … (10)

   Thus the magnitude of the velocity of either rod (i.e. of its centre of mass) just
   before the rods come down flat onto the table is

   v = (1/2)√(3 g l sin θ₀).

### Final Answer  
\[
\boxed{\, v = \dfrac{1}{2}\,\sqrt{3\,g\,l \,\sin\theta_{0}} \,}
\]

questions:
An arbitrary multi-terminal resistor network structure, for example with $N+1$ terminals, sets one specific terminal (0 terminal) as the reference for electric potential, setting its potential at 0. The potentials for other terminals (numbered 1, 2, ..., N) are $v_{1}, v_{2}, \ldots, v_{N}$, and the current flowing into the network through these corresponding terminals (negative when flowing out) are $I_{1}, I_2, \ldots, I_n$. Therefore, we have:

$$
\left\{
\begin{array}{l}
V_{1} = a_{11} I_{1} + a_{12} I_{2} + \cdots + a_{1N} I_{N} \\
V_{2} = a_{21} I_{1} + a_{22} I_{2} + \cdots + a_{2N} I_{N} \\
\vdots \\
V_{i} = a_{i1} I_{1} + a_{i2} I_{2} + \cdots + a_{iN} I_{N} \\
\vdots \\
V_{N} = a_{N1} I_{1} + a_{N2} I_{2} + \cdots + a_{NN} I_{N} 
\end{array}
\right.
$$

Due to symmetry, we know that $a_{ij} = a_{ji}$.

This means that the properties of the $N+1$ terminal network can be determined by $\frac{N(N+1)}{2}$ independent parameters: $a_{11}, a_{12}, \ldots , a_{ij}, \ldots , a_{NN} (i<j)$. These parameters are only determined by the resistor network itself and are unrelated to the potential at the terminals or the magnitude of the current flowing in.

Consider a square uniform conductive thin plate as a four-terminal resistor network. The four vertices are sequentially numbered clockwise as 0, 1, 2, 3. If the equivalent resistance between adjacent vertices is ${R}_{1}$ and the equivalent resistance between opposite vertices is ${{R}}_{2}$, use the method of finding the coefficients $a_{i j} (i,j=1,2,3)$ to solve: what is the equivalent resistance between the other two vertices if a pair of adjacent vertices is short-circuited?
solutions:
For this situation, label the 4 endpoints sequentially as 0, 1, 2, 3. If current flows into endpoint 1 with current I (flowing out from endpoint 0), then:   

$$
V_{1}=a_{11}I=I R_{1}
$$  

Thus, we obtain: $a_{11}=R_{1}$  

Similarly, if current flows into endpoints 2 or 3 with current I, we can respectively obtain: $a_{22}=R_{2}$ $a_{33}=R_{1}$. If current flows into endpoint 1 with current I and flows out from endpoint 2:  

$$
V_{1}^{\prime}=a_{11}I-a_{12}I,V_{2}^{\prime}=a_{21}I-a_{22}I
$$  

At this moment, the potential difference between endpoints 1 and 2 is:  

$$
V_{1}^{\prime}-V_{2}^{\prime}=(a_{11}-2a_{12}+a_{22})I
$$  

Due to symmetry, at this moment, the potential difference between endpoints 1 and 2 should be equal to the potential at endpoint 1 (between 1 and 0) when current flows only into endpoint 1 (out from endpoint 0), thus:  

$$
(a_{11}-2a_{12}+a_{22})I=a_{11}I
$$  

We obtain:  

$$
a_{12}=\frac{1}{2}a_{22}=\frac{1}{2}R_{2}
$$  

[This can also be directly obtained by the condition of current input into endpoint 2, where the potential at endpoint 1 is half of that at endpoint 2 due to symmetry.] Similarly, we obtain:  

$$
a_{23}=\frac{1}{2}R_{2}
$$  

Returning again to the situation with current flowing only into endpoint 1 (flowing out from endpoint 0), at this moment, the potentials at endpoints 2 and 3 are respectively:  

$$
V_{2}=a_{21}I,V_{3}=a_{31}I
$$  

Due to symmetry, the potential difference between endpoints 1 and 2 should be equal to the potential difference between endpoints 3 and 0, thus:  

$$
V_{1}-V_{2}=V_{3}
$$  

Therefore:  

$$
a_{11}I-a_{21}I=a_{31}I
$$  

We obtain:  

$$
a_{13}=a_{31}=a_{11}-a_{12}=R_{1}-{\frac{1}{2}}R_{2}
$$  

Now returning to the required situation of the problem, without loss of generality, we can assume endpoints 3 and 0 are short-circuited and calculate the equivalent resistance between endpoints 1 and 2. In this case, if current flows into endpoint 1 with current I and out from endpoint 2, since endpoints 3 and 0 are short-circuited, there must be current flowing from 0 through the short-circuit wire into endpoint 3. Let the current flowing through the short-circuit wire be $I^{\prime}$, then it can be considered as the original four-terminal situation with current flowing into endpoint 1, out from endpoint 2, and into endpoint 3 with $I^{\prime}$. At this moment, the potential at endpoint 3 is:  

$$
V_{3}=a_{31}I-a_{32}I+a_{33}I^{\prime}
$$  

Because 3 and 0 are practically short-circuited, $V_{3}$ should be 0. Thus we can compute:  

$$
I^{\prime}=\frac{a_{32}-a_{31}}{a_{33}}I=\frac{R_{2}-R_{1}}{R_{1}}I
$$  

We can then compute the potentials at endpoints 1 and 2:  

The potential difference between endpoints 1 and 2:  

$$
\begin{array}{c}{{V_{1}=a_{11}I-a_{12}I+a_{13}I^{\prime}=(R_{1}-\displaystyle{\frac{1}{2}}R_{2})\displaystyle{\frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}}}I}}\ {{V_{2}=a_{21}I-a_{22}I+a_{23}I^{\prime}=\displaystyle{\frac{R_{2}}{2}}\displaystyle{\frac{R_{2}-2R_{1}}{R_{1}}}I}}\end{array}
$$  

$$
V_{1}-V_{2}=\frac{(2R_{1}-R_{2})R_{2}}{2R_{1}}I
$$  

Thus, the equivalent resistance between endpoints 1 and 2 is:  

$$
R={\frac{V_{1}-V_{2}}{I}}={\frac{(2R_{1}-R_{2})R_{2}}{2R_{1}}}=(2-{\frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}}})R_{2}
$$

Let the four corners of the square conducting plate be numbered (clock-wise)  

0 – 1 – 2 – 3, and choose corner 0 as the reference node ( V₀ ≡0 ).  
With the notation of the problem we have for the three remaining terminals  

V = A I ,  A = (a_{ij})\_{3\times 3},  a_{ij}=a_{ji}.             (1)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Express the two measured open-circuit resistances with the a_{ij}
--------------------------------------------------------------------
a)  Between two adjacent vertices, e.g. 1 and 2  
 Inject a current +I at 1, take –I out at 2 and keep the other two
 corners open (I₃ = 0).  
 Then  I₁ = +I , I₂ = –I , I₃ = 0.

 V₁ = a₁₁I₁ + a₁₂I₂ = (a₁₁-a₁₂)I
 V₂ = a₁₂I₁ + a₂₂I₂ = (a₁₂-a₂₂)I

 Hence the voltage difference is  
 V₁ – V₂ = (a₁₁ + a₂₂ – 2a₁₂)I.

 The open-circuit resistance between adjacent corners is therefore  

 R₁  ≡ R\_{adj} = a₁₁ + a₂₂ – 2a₁₂.                             (2)

b)  Between two opposite vertices, e.g. 1 and 3  
 Inject +I at 1, take –I out at 3, I₂ = 0 :

 V₁ – V₃ = (a₁₁ + a₃₃ – 2a₁₃)I.

 Hence  

 R₂ ≡ R\_{opp} = a₁₁ + a₃₃ – 2a₁₃.                             (3)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Use geometrical symmetry of the square plate
--------------------------------------------------------------------
The plate is symmetric with respect to the diagonal 0–2.  
That reflection interchanges corners 1 ↔ 3 while leaving
0 and 2 unchanged, therefore  

a₁₁ = a₃₃ ,               a₁₂ = a₂₃.                          (4)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Relate the remaining a_{ij} to R₁ and R₂
--------------------------------------------------------------------
•  Resistance between corners 0 and 1 (they are also an adjacent pair)
   with 2 and 3 open:  V₁/I = a₁₁ = R₁.                        (5)

•  Resistance between corners 0 and 2 (they are opposite):
   V₂/I = a₂₂ = R₂.                                            (6)

With (4), (5), (6) inserted in (2) and (3) we get

a₁₂ = a₂₃ = R₂/2,                                             (7)
a₁₃ = a₁₁ - R₂/2 = R₁ - R₂/2.                                 (8)

Thus the whole matrix A is now expressed through the two measured
quantities R₁ and R₂ :

a₁₁ = a₃₃ = R₁,    a₂₂ = R₂,    a₁₂ = a₂₃ = R₂/2,    a₁₃ = R₁ - R₂/2.   (9)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Short–circuit the adjacent pair 1–2 and find the required
    equivalent resistance between the remaining pair 0–3
--------------------------------------------------------------------
After shorting 1 and 2 we have the constraint  

V₁ = V₂ .                                                     (10)

Let an external current I enter the plate at corner 3 and leave at
corner 0 (the reference).  
Because the shorted pair 1–2 is not connected to the external circuit,
the algebraic external current through it is zero, i.e.

I₁ + I₂ = 0.  Write I₁ = +J, I₂ = –J.                         (11)

With (1) the condition (10) gives

0 = V₁ – V₂  
  = (a₁₁ + a₂₂ − 2a₁₂)J + (a₁₃ − a₂₃)I                        (12)

Using (9) and the definition R₁ = a₁₁ + a₂₂ − 2a₁₂ we obtain

J = (a₂₃ − a₁₃) I / R₁ = (R₁ − R₂) I / R₁.                    (13)

V₃ = a₃₁I₁ + a₃₂I₂ + a₃₃I

Insert (13) and the coefficients (9):

V₃ = −(R₁ − R₂)² I / R₁ + R₁ I.                               (15)

Hence the desired equivalent resistance between corner 3 and the
reference node 0 (with 1 and 2 shorted) is  

R_eq = V₃ / I = R₁ − (R₁ − R₂)² / R₁

       = (R₂ (2R₁ − R₂))/R₁.                                  (16)

\[
\boxed{\,R_{\text{equiv}}=\dfrac{R_{2}\left(2R_{1}-R_{2}\right)}{R_{1}}\,}
\]

questions: Consider a semi-infinite solenoid with radius $R$, turns per unit length $n$, connected to a constant current source with current $I$. To facilitate subsequent calculations, we establish a cylindrical coordinate system such that the $z$-axis coincides with the symmetry axis of the solenoid. The solenoid extends from the origin along the negative $z$-axis to infinity, and the current is viewed as rotating counterclockwise when observed from above the $z$-axis, meaning the direction of the current is in the positive $\hat{\theta}$ direction. Now, a superconducting metal ring is placed such that some constraint keeps the symmetry axis of the current loop always coinciding with the $z$-axis, allowing it to move freely up and down in this state. It is known that at the instant the metal ring transitions from normal to superconducting state, a current $I_{0}$ flows within the ring, and there is no other external magnetic field at a sufficiently far distance from the solenoid. $I_{0}$ flows in the positive $\hat{\theta}$ direction. Subsequently, the metal ring remains in the superconducting state. Assume the gravitational acceleration is $\overrightarrow{g}=-g\widehat{z}$, the mass of the metal ring is $m$, and it is of uniform density. Let $z_{0}>0$ be known. If the equilibrium is stable, find the vibration period $T$ near the equilibrium position (expressed in terms of $n$, $I_{0}$, $r$, $R$, $L$, $m$), and the answer may include $z_{0}$. It is known that the radius of the metal ring is $r \ll R$, and the self-inductance is $L$.
solutions:
The equilibrium condition is

$$
F(z)=m g
$$

$$
\frac{\pi}{2}\mu_{0}n I R^{2}r^{2}\frac{1}{(z^{2}+R^{2})^{3/2}}(\frac{\mu_{0}n I\pi r^{2}}{2L}(1-\frac{z}{\sqrt{z^{2}+R^{2}}})-I_{0})=m g
$$

Consider the stability of the equilibrium. If $\frac{d F}{d z}$ is negative, then the equilibrium is stable; otherwise, it is unstable.

$$
\left.{\frac{d F}{d z}}\right|_{z_{0}}={\frac{\pi}{2}}\mu_{0}n I R^{2}r^{2}\cdot[({\frac{\mu_{0}n I\pi r^{2}}{2L}}-I_{0}){\frac{-3z_{0}}{(z_{0}^{2}+R^{2})^{5/2}}}+{\frac{\mu_{0}n I\pi r^{2}}{2L}}{\frac{3z_{0}^{2}-R^{2}}{(z_{0}^{2}+R^{2})^{3}}}]
$$

Therefore, the requirement for stability is

$$
\frac{3z_{0}^{2}-R^{2}}{3z_{0}\sqrt{z_{0}^{2}+R^{2}}}<1-\frac{2I_{0}L}{\mu_{0}n I\pi r^{2}}
$$

If the equilibrium is stable, then

$$
T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{m}{\left.\displaystyle-\frac{d F}{d z}\right|_{z_{0}}}}
$$

$$
T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{m}{\frac{\pi}{2}\mu_{0}n I R^{2}r^{2}\cdot[(\frac{\mu_{0}n I\pi r^{2}}{2L}-I_{0})\frac{3z_{0}}{(z_{0}^{2}+R^{2})^{5/2}}-\frac{\mu_{0}n I\pi r^{2}}{2L}\frac{3z_{0}^{2}-R^{2}}{(z_{0}^{2}+R^{2})^{3}}]}}
$$

Let the centre of the light, thin metal ring be on the axis of the (semi-infinite) solenoid at the position

The radius of the ring is r ( r  ≪  R ) and its self–inductance is L.  
The current in the ring is called i(t)  ( i>0 corresponds to the anticlock-wise sense, i.e. the +\hat{\theta } direction).

1.  Magnetic field of the semi–infinite solenoid on the axis  

With the linear turn density n and current I in the coil one may regard the solenoid as a stack of infinitesimal circular loops.  
For a loop situated at coordinate z′ ( z′ ≤ 0 ) the on–axis field is  

 dB = μ0 I R² / [ 2 ( R² + (z – z′)² )^{3/2} ] n dz′ .  

Integrating from z′ = –∞ to z′ = 0 gives the field that threads the ring situated at z(>0):

 B(z) = μ0 n I 2⁻¹ [ 1 – z / √( z² + R²) ] ≡ H    (1)

Hence

 dB/dz = – ( μ0 n I /2 ) R² / ( z² + R² )^{3/2}.  (2)

Define for abbreviation  

 s(z) ≡ √( z² + R² ) ,  H ≡ μ0 n I /2 .                                                     (3)

2.  Flux conservation in the superconducting ring  

After the ring becomes superconducting the total flux through it must remain equal to its value at the instant of transition (t = 0).  
Denoting that initial position by z0 and the corresponding current in the ring by I0,

 Φ(t) = L i(t) + π r² B[ z(t) ] = L I0 + π r² B( z0 ) = const.    (4)

Hence the current for an arbitrary small displacement is

 i(z) = I0 + ( π r² /L ) [ B(z0 ) – B(z) ].                              (5)

3.  Force acting on the ring  

The magnetic moment of the ring is  

 μ = i(z) · (π r²) \hat{z}.  

The axial force is

 Fmag = μ ( dB/dz )                                                    (6)

Using (2) and writing C ≡ π r² H R² , one obtains

 Fmag (z) = – C i(z) / s³(z) .                                          (7)

The total (vertical) force

 F(z) = Fmag (z) – m g .                                               (8)

4.  Condition for static equilibrium  

At the equilibrium position ( z = z0 )

 F(z0 ) = 0  →  m g = C I0 / s³_0 ,  s0 ≡ s(z0 ).                    (9)

5.  Restoring force constant  

For small oscillations let z = z0 + ξ ( |ξ| ≪ z0 ).  
Expand F(z) to first order in ξ :

 F(z) ≃ –k ξ ,  k = – ( dF/dz )_{z0} .                               (10)

From (7) and (5)

 d i /dz = – ( π r² /L ) dB/dz = + C / ( L s³ ).                       (11)

The angular frequency ω and the period T are therefore

 ω = √( k /m ) ,  T = 2π / ω = 2π √{ m /k } .

with

When the denominator of (13) is positive the equilibrium is stable; if it approaches zero the period grows without bound, signalling the border of stability.

 }\;

questions: Two dielectric materials with base areas both equal to $\pmb{A}$, thicknesses of $h_{1}$ and $h_{2}$ respectively, dielectric constants of $\varepsilon_{1}$ and $\varepsilon_{2}$ respectively, and conductivities of $\sigma_{1}$ and $\sigma_{2}$ respectively, are placed tightly between two highly conductive flat plates with the same area $\pmb{A}$ and a separation distance of $(h_{1}+h_{2})$, forming a capacitor. The system is connected into a circuit , with a power source of electromotive force $U_{0}$. Initially, the capacitor is uncharged, and at $\scriptstyle t=0$, the switch is turned on. Determine the time-dependent relationship of the current $I(t)$ flowing through the switch for $t > 0$.
solutions:
Let the magnitudes of the electric field intensity in the two media be $E_{1}, E_{2}$ respectively, and according to the relationship between the electric potentials, we have  

$$
E_{1}h_{1} + E_{2}h_{2} = U_{0}
$$  

The magnitudes of the current density in the two media are  

$$
\begin{aligned}
    j_1 &= \sigma_1 E_1, \\
    j_2 &= \sigma_2 E_2.
\end{aligned}
$$  

Let the free charge surface density at the contact of the two media be $\sigma_{\bullet}$, then  

From this, we obtain  

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l l}{\displaystyle{\frac{\mathrm{d}\sigma_{\circ}}{\mathrm{d}t}}=j_{1}-j_{2}}\ {\sigma_{\circ}=\varepsilon_{2}E_{2}-\varepsilon_{1}E_{1}}\end{array}\right.
$$  

$$
U_{0} = \frac{\mathrm{d}\sigma_{0}}{\mathrm{d}t}\cdot\left(\frac{h_{1}\varepsilon_{2} + h_{2}\varepsilon_{1}}{\sigma_{1}\varepsilon_{2} - \sigma_{2}\varepsilon_{1}}\right) + \sigma_{0}\cdot\left(\frac{\sigma_{1}h_{2} + \sigma_{2}h_{1}}{\sigma_{1}\varepsilon_{2} - \sigma_{2}\varepsilon_{1}}\right)
$$  

That is  

$$
\sigma_{0} = \frac{U_{0}\left(\sigma_{1}\varepsilon_{2} - \sigma_{2}\varepsilon_{1}\right)}{\sigma_{1}h_{2} + \sigma_{2}h_{1}}\cdot\left(1-\mathrm{e}^{\frac{t}{\tau}}\right)
$$  

Where the time constant is  

$$
\tau = \frac{h_{1}\varepsilon_{2} + h_{2}\varepsilon_{1}}{h_{1}\sigma_{2} + h_{2}\sigma_{1}}
$$  

The current in the circuit can be obtained as  

$$
I = A{\left(\sigma_{1}E_{1} + \varepsilon_{1}{\frac{\mathrm{d}E_{1}}{\mathrm{d}t}}\right)} = A{\left(\sigma_{2}E_{2} + \varepsilon_{2}{\frac{\mathrm{d}E_{2}}{\mathrm{d}t}}\right)}
$$  

Substitute in to get  

$$
I = A U_{0}\cdot\left[\frac{\sigma_{1}\sigma_{2}}{\sigma_{1}h_{2}+\sigma_{2}h_{1}} + \mathrm{e}^{\frac{\sigma_{1}h_{2}+\sigma_{2}h_{1}}{\varepsilon_{1}h_{2}+\varepsilon_{2}h_{1}}t}\cdot\left(\frac{\varepsilon_{2}\sigma_{1}+\varepsilon_{1}\sigma_{2}}{\varepsilon_{1}h_{2}+\varepsilon_{2}h_{1}} - \frac{\sigma_{1}\sigma_{2}}{\sigma_{1}h_{2}+\sigma_{2}h_{1}} - \frac{\varepsilon_{1}\varepsilon_{2}\left(\sigma_{1}h_{2}+\sigma_{2}h_{1}\right)}{\left(\varepsilon_{1}h_{2}+\varepsilon_{2}h_{1}\right)^{2}}\right)\right]
$$
final_answers:
$$
I = A U_0 \left[\frac{\sigma_1 \sigma_2}{\sigma_1 h_2 + \sigma_2 h_1} + e^{-\frac{\sigma_1 h_2 + \sigma_2 h_1}{\varepsilon_1 h_2 + \varepsilon_2 h_1} t} \left(\frac{\varepsilon_2 \sigma_1 + \varepsilon_1 \sigma_2}{\varepsilon_1 h_2 + \varepsilon_2 h_1} - \frac{\sigma_1 \sigma_2}{\sigma_1 h_2 + \sigma_2 h_1} - \frac{\varepsilon_1 \varepsilon_2 (\sigma_1 h_2 + \sigma_2 h_1)}{(\varepsilon_1 h_2 + \varepsilon_2 h_1)^2} \right)\right]
$$

Below the whole reasoning is written step by step.  
The boxed formula in the last section is the requested final result.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------

1.  Equivalent currents inside each slab  
   For a homogeneous dielectric with permittivity ε and conductivity σ the total (conduction + displacement) current density is  

   J = Jσ + JD = σE + ε ∂E/∂t                         …(1)

   In the present capacitor both slabs are connected in series, therefore the
   same (surface) current density  

   J(t) = I(t)/A                                           …(2)

   flows through the two layers:

   σ1E1 + ε1 ẊE1  =  σ2E2 + ε2 ẊE2  = J(t)               …(3)

   The electric fields are assumed uniform because the plates are large and
   conduct perfectly.

2.  Total voltage supplied by the source  

   U0  =  h1E1 + h2E2                                    …(4)

   (the battery is an ideal step: U = U0 H(t) with zero internal impedance).

3.  One first–order differential equation  
   Eliminate E2 from (3) with the help of (4):

        E2 = (U0 – h1E1)/h2.  
   Substituting this in (3) gives  

        [σ1 + σ2 h1/h2]E1  +  [ε1 + ε2 h1/h2] ẊE1  =  (σ2U0)/h2.   …(5)

   Writing  

        α = σ1 + σ2 h1/h2 , β = ε1 + ε2 h1/h2 , τ = β/α      …(6)

   eq.(5) becomes  

        β ẊE1 + αE1 = (σ2U0)/h2 .                           …(7)

   This is a first–order linear ODE whose solution is

        E1(t) = E1(∞) + [E1(0) – E1(∞)] e^{–t/τ}.            …(8)

4.  Initial and steady–state electric fields  

   • at t = 0⁺ (no free charge yet on the interface) D⊥ is continuous:  
          ε1E1(0) = ε2E2(0).  
     With (4) one finds  

          E1(0) = U0 / [h1 + h2 ε1/ε2].                    …(9)

   • for t → ∞ only the ohmic part remains, so the conduction currents in
     the two layers are equal: σ1E1(∞) = σ2E2(∞).  
     With (4)  

          E1(∞) = U0 / [h1 + h2 σ1/σ2].                    …(10)

5.  Current through the switch  
   From (1) & (2)

        J(t) = σ1E1(t) + ε1 ẊE1(t).                        …(11)

   Using (8) and the definitions (6) one finally obtains

        J(t) = J∞ + (J0 – J∞) e^{–t/τ},                    …(12)

   with  

        J∞ = σ1E1(∞) = σ2E2(∞)
            = U0 / (h1/σ1 + h2/σ2),                        …(13)

        J0 = σ1E1(0) + ε1 ẊE1(0)
           = [h1σ1ε2² + h2σ2ε1²] U0 /(h1ε2 + h2ε1)².       …(14)

   Multiplying by the plate area A gives the current through the switch:

        I(t) = I∞ + (I0 – I∞) e^{–t/τ},                    …(15)

   where  

        τ = (h2ε1 + h1ε2) / (h2σ1 + h1σ2),                 …(16)

        I∞ = A U0 / (h1/σ1 + h2/σ2),                       …(17)

        I0 = A U0 [h1σ1ε2² + h2σ2ε1²] /(h1ε2 + h2ε1)².     …(18)

   A more compact form for the transient amplitude is

        I0 – I∞
        = A U0 h1h2 (σ1ε2 – ε1σ2)² /
          [ (h1ε2 + h2ε1)² (h1σ2 + h2σ1) ].                …(19)

   All formulas hold for absolute permittivities ε1, ε2 (ε = ε0 εr if
   dielectric constants are given).

   Notice  
   • If the two media are identical (ε1=ε2, σ1=σ2) then I0 = I∞ and the
     exponential term vanishes, as expected.  
   • For σ1→0 or σ2→0 the long-time current tends to zero and the result
     reduces to that of an ordinary (perfect) series capacitor.

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{
\displaystyle
I(t)=I_{\infty}+\bigl(I_{0}-I_{\infty}\bigr)\,e^{-t/\tau},
\qquad t>0
}
\]

with  

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\tau &=\frac{h_{2}\,\varepsilon_{1}+h_{1}\,\varepsilon_{2}}
            {h_{2}\,\sigma_{1}+h_{1}\,\sigma_{2}},\\[4pt]
I_{\infty}&=\frac{A\,U_{0}}
                 {\dfrac{h_{1}}{\sigma_{1}}+\dfrac{h_{2}}{\sigma_{2}}},\\[6pt]
I_{0}&=A\,U_{0}\,
      \frac{h_{1}\sigma_{1}\varepsilon_{2}^{2}+h_{2}\sigma_{2}\varepsilon_{1}^{2}}
           {(h_{1}\varepsilon_{2}+h_{2}\varepsilon_{1})^{2}}
      =I_{\infty}+A\,U_{0}\,
        \frac{h_{1}h_{2}(\sigma_{1}\varepsilon_{2}-\varepsilon_{1}\sigma_{2})^{2}}
             {(h_{1}\varepsilon_{2}+h_{2}\varepsilon_{1})^{2}
              (h_{1}\sigma_{2}+h_{2}\sigma_{1})}.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

Here  
A  – plate area,  
h₁, h₂ – thicknesses of the two dielectric slabs,  
ε₁, ε₂ – (absolute) permittivities,  
σ₁, σ₂ – conductivities,  
U₀ – step voltage of the source.

questions:
There is an available cycloidal valley, which can be described using a cycloid (downward along the $y$-axis): 
$$
\left\{{\begin{array}{l}{x=R(\theta-\sin\theta)}\\ {y=R(1-\cos\theta)}\end{array}}\right.
$$
 Someone wants to release a cube with a mass of $M$ and with equal length, width, and height of $r$ at rest from one end of the valley at $\theta = 0$. It is released facing the slope. A layer of snow with a surface density of $\sigma$ is attached to the valley. The snow is in contact with the ground but does not interact, remaining stationary until it touches the object, at which point it adheres to its surface without altering the object's shape. Assuming gravitational acceleration $g$, there are the approximate conditions $\sigma r R \ll M, r \ll R$ (results are retained up to the first order of $r$). Determine the highest position the cube can reach at the other end (considering no rolling occurs).
solutions: In this sub-question, energy is not conserved, but analyzing its motion still presents certain difficulties. Considering that the problem only requires accuracy to the first-order term, the loss of ascent quotient can be divided into two parts for correction, with zero-order motion considered during the correction process.  For the collision process between the square block and the snow, consider the conservation of momentum:  $$ M v = (M + \sigma\gamma u{\mathrm{d}}t)(v - {\mathrm{d}}v) $$  This results in:  $$ \mathrm{d}\upsilon = -\frac{\sigma r v^{2}}{M}\mathrm{d}t $$  The energy loss during the process is:  $$ d E = \frac{1}{2}(M + \mathrm{d}M)(\upsilon + \mathrm{d}\upsilon)^{2} - \frac{1}{2}(M)\upsilon^{2} = -\frac{1}{2}\sigma r\upsilon^{2}\upsilon\mathrm{d}t = -\frac{1}{2}\sigma r\upsilon^{2}\mathrm{d}s $$  In this case, it can be treated as linear motion, and the equation is not influenced by acceleration. Therefore, it can be corrected independently, with the zero-order velocity expression as:  $$ \upsilon_{0} = \sqrt{2g R(1-\cos\theta)} $$  Substituting into the integral:  $$ \delta W = \int f\mathrm{d}s = \int_{0}^{2\pi} -g R(1-\cos\theta)\sigma\boldsymbol{r}\cdot2R\sin\frac{\theta}{2}\mathrm{d}\theta = -\frac{32}{3}g R^{2}r\sigma $$  This gives the energy loss caused by collisions, which we convert into a height correction, then combine it with the correction for the gravitational component of the snow from the first question, resulting in the total reached height:  $$ \begin{array}{l} {{\delta y_{f} = \displaystyle\frac{32}{3}\displaystyle\frac{\sigma R^{2}r}{M}}}{{}}\\ {{\delta y_{g} = \displaystyle\frac{32}{3}\displaystyle\frac{\sigma R^{2}r}{M}}}{{}}\\ {{\delta y = \displaystyle\frac{64}{3}\displaystyle\frac{\sigma R^{2}r}{M}}} \end{array} $$  The two combined terms are both first-order and do not interfere with each other.
improved_solutions:
Solution Outline  
1. Geometry of the track  
 Cycloid (0 ≤ θ ≤ 2π)  
 x(θ)=R(θ−sinθ) , y(θ)=R(1−cosθ)  (y is measured vertically downward)  

 Arc–length element  
 dx/dθ=R(1−cosθ), dy/dθ=R sinθ  
 ds=√[(dx/dθ)²+(dy/dθ)²]dθ=2R sin(θ/2)dθ.  

2. Snow that is picked up  
 Cube edge = r (bottom face area r×r).  
 When the cube advances ds it sweeps a ground area r ds.  
 Surface density of snow = σ ⇒ infinitesimal accreted mass  

 dm = σr ds = 2σrR sin(θ/2)dθ.  (1)

3. Energy balance for a body that sticks to resting particles  
 At the instant the cube of mass m and speed v sticks to dm at rest

 Momentum  mv = (m+dm)(v+dv) ⟹ dv = −(v/m)dm.  

 Kinetic–energy change  
 dK = ½v²dm + mv dv = −½v²dm.  (2)

 Take y positive downward, potential U = −mgy.  
 For the cube (+ already picked snow)  

 d(K+U) = dK − gy dm − mg dy  
 Using (2) and mv dv+mg dy = −½v²dm one finds  

 dE = d(K+U) = −gy dm.  (3)

4. Integrating from the release point (θ=0, E=0) to the turning point θ=θₘ (v=0)  

 E_final = −m_f gy_f , E_initial = 0.  
 With (3)  −m_f gy_f = −g∫₀^{θₘ} y dm   

 ⇒ m_f y_f = ∫₀^{θₘ} y dm.  (4)

 Here  
 y(θ)=R(1−cosθ), y_f = y(θₘ)=R(1−cosθₘ),  
 dm given by (1), m_f = M + ∫₀^{θₘ}dm.

5. Carrying out the integrals  
 Total collected snow  
 m_s = ∫₀^{θₘ}dm = 2σrR∫₀^{θₘ}sin(θ/2)dθ  
    = 4σrR[1−cos(θₘ/2)].  (5)

 Integral in (4)  
 I ≡ ∫₀^{θₘ} y dm  
  = 2σrR²∫₀^{θₘ}(1−cosθ)sin(θ/2)dθ  
  = 4σrR²∫₀^{θₘ}sin³(θ/2)dθ  

 Put u=θ/2 (θ=2u, dθ=2du):

 I = 8σrR²∫₀^{θₘ/2}sin³u du  
   = 8σrR² [ −cosu + (cos³u)/3 ]₀^{θₘ/2}  
   = 8σrR²\Bigl[\frac{2}{3} - cos(θₘ/2) +\frac{1}{3}cos^{3}(θₘ/2)\Bigr]. (6)

6. Equation for θₘ  
 Insert (5) and (6) into (4):

 [ M + 4σrR(1−cos(θₘ/2)) ] R(1−cosθₘ)  
  = 8σrR²\Bigl[\frac{2}{3} - cos(θₘ/2) +\frac{1}{3}cos^{3}(θₘ/2)\Bigr]. (7)

7. Use σrR ≪ M ( keep first order in ε = 4σrR/M )  
 Write c ≡ cos(θₘ/2), ε ≡ 4σrR/M  (ε ≪ 1)

 1−cosθₘ = 2(1−c²) = 2(1−c)(1+c) ≈ 2(1−c)(−1) (for c near −1)  
 Because without snow θₘ=2π ⇒ c=cosπ=−1; set θₘ=2π−δ, δ≪1  

 c = cos(π−δ/2) = −cos(δ/2) ≈ −1 + δ²/8,  
 1−cosθₘ ≈ δ²/2.                                               (8)

 For the right–hand side of (7) one finds to first order in δ  

 2\Bigl[\frac{2}{3} - c +\frac{1}{3}c^{3}\Bigr] = \frac{8}{3}.  

 Equation (7) therefore gives (using 1/(1+ε(1−c))≃1)

 δ²/2 = \frac{8}{3}ε   ⟹  δ = \frac{8}{\sqrt{3}}\sqrt{ε}. (9)

8. Turning position  

 ε = 4σrR/M, so  

 θₘ = 2π − \frac{8}{\sqrt{3}}\sqrt{\frac{4σrR}{M}}  
   = 2π − \frac{8}{\sqrt{3}}\sqrt{\frac{σrR}{M}}.  (10)

 Vertical short–fall (depth reached measured from the cusp)

 y_f = R(1−cosθₘ) ≈ \frac{δ²}{2}R  
   = \frac{8}{3}εR  
   = \frac{32}{3}\frac{σrR^{2}}{M}.  (11)

Hence the cube fails to climb back to the original cusp by the small height (32/3)(σrR²/M).  

Its highest point on the far side is situated at parameter value

 θ_f ≃ 2π − (8/√3)√(σrR/M).

### Final Answer  
To first order in the small parameter σrR/M the far–side turning point of the cube is  

\[
\boxed{\;
\theta_{\text{max}} \;=\; 2\pi-\frac{8}{\sqrt{3}}\,
    \sqrt{\frac{\sigma\,r\,R}{M}}\;
}
\]

equivalently, the cube stops a vertical distance  

\[
\boxed{\;
y_{\text{max}} \;=\; R\!\left(1-\cos\theta_{\text{max}}\right)
          \;=\; \frac{32}{3}\,
                 \frac{\sigma\,r\,R^{2}}{M}
\;}
\]

below the top cusp from which it was released.
